title: Birth of a Salesman
text:
"Birth of a Salesman" is a <a href="short%20story">short story</a> by <a href="P.%20G.%20Wodehouse">P. G. Wodehouse</a>, which first appeared in the United States in the 26 March 1950 issue of "<a href="This%20Week%20%28magazine%29">This Week</a>" magazine. Part of the <a href="Blandings%20Castle">Blandings Castle</a> canon, it features the absent-minded peer <a href="Lord%20Emsworth">Lord Emsworth</a>, and was included in the collection "<a href="Nothing%20Serious%20%28short%20stories%29">Nothing Serious</a>" (1950).
The story's title is a play on "<a href="Death%20of%20a%20Salesman">Death of a Salesman</a>", the now-classic stageplay by <a href="Arthur%20Miller">Arthur Miller</a>, which had won a <a href="Pulitzer%20Prize">Pulitzer Prize</a> the previous year.
Plot summary.
Lord Emsworth is visiting America for the wedding of his niece <a href="List%20of%20minor%20Blandings%20characters%23Veronica%20Wedge">Veronica</a> to millionaire <a href="List%20of%20minor%20Blandings%20characters%23Tipton%20Plimsoll">Tipton Plimsoll</a>. With currency restrictions forcing him to stay at <a href="Freddie%20Threepwood">Freddie</a>'s house in <a href="Long%20Island">Long Island</a>, Emsworth finds himself ill at ease, chafed by his son's new-found self-confidence, the result of his successes as a salesman.
Left alone in the house one day, Emsworth finds the cold lunch left for him unappealing, and resolves to fix himself some <a href="scrambled%20eggs">scrambled eggs</a>. This task proves more difficult than he recalled from his more active youth, and when a young girl calls at the door selling richly bound <a href="encyclopedia">encyclopaedias</a> of Sport, he invites her in to make them for him and join him at his lunch.
The girl, who is only known as "<a href="List%20of%20minor%20Blandings%20characters%23Mrs%20Ed">Mrs Ed</a>", reveals she is trying to earn money, as she has a baby on the way. Emsworth's sense of chivalry is aroused, and he offers to sell her encyclopaedias for her, while she has a lie down on the couch. He heads at once for the house of a near neighbour, who Freddie had earlier warned him had a conspicuous habit of throwing wild parties and filling his house with blondes while his wife was away. This behaviour, striking Emsworth as indicative of a sporting nature, persuades the elderly peer that the man must also be in need of his encyclopaedias.
Nervously approaching the house, Emsworth is embarrassed by a carful of blondes, but carries on manfully. After a failed attempt to knock at the door, a <a href="Pekinese">Pekinese</a> named Eisenhower, property of one of the blondes, chases him up a tree. The homeowner, lumber king <a href="List%20of%20minor%20Blandings%20characters%23George%20Spenlow">George Spenlow</a>, already unnerved having seen Emsworth mooning over his flower beds earlier in the day, mistakes him for a <a href="Private%20investigator">private eye</a> in the hire of his wife.
He approaches Emsworth and offers him a bribe, which Emsworth innocently confuses with an offer to buy his encyclopaedias. He takes the man's $500, and quietly slips it into Mrs Ed's handbag while she sleeps, resolving to put a stop to his son's arrogance right away.
Publication history.
The story was illustrated by Glen Fleischmann in "This Week".
